Selected Answer: BD
B. Configure the devices to use an always-on IPSec VPN
D. Implement a VDI solution and deploy supporting client apps to devices

I read "corporate-owned mobility infrastructure" as including company issued laptops for potentially traveling employees. The company can implement a VDI solution and monitor web browsing that way.

I don't see how "establishing only HTTPS connections outside the enterprise boundary" does anything for monitoring...?

"Remote access: VDI users can connect to their virtual desktop from any location or device, making it easy for employees to access all their files and applications and work remotely from anywhere in the world."
https://www.vmware.com/topics/glossary/content/virtual-desktop-infrastructure-vdi.html

Maybe: D. Implement a VDI solution and deploy supporting client apps to devices ?
VDI ensures that no data is kept on the mobile device (Laptop etc.) and all is kept on the company network, allowing it to be monitored.

Given answer is correct
B. Configure the devices to use an always-on IPSec VPN, this requires devices to connect back to corporate network in order to connect anywhere else, establishing a private tunnel in.
E. Restrict application permissions to establish only HTTPS connections outside of the enterprise boundary , forcing HTTPS-only connections out allows you to place a listener proxy in the middle of the connection. Allow other ports in or out of the enterprise would make monitoring more difficult. Requiring HTTPS will allow you to inspect and log all traffic from mobile devices.

That person's own phone is not a corporate resource. But within the premises, everything is setup to use HTTP, which is easily monitored. So if you use your phone on the premises, any HTTP will be monitored.

Why does "HTTPS-only connections out allows you to place a listener proxy in the middle of the connection?" Any more so than HTTP? I would think a listener would be more effective with HTTP because HTTP is not encrypted.
You are correct the answer is B and E
Not sure what I was saying here..... must have needed some coffee.... B and D are the best answers here.

Actually idk. Just ignore all my input from here on. If we are connecting from a corporate owned mobile device, vdi doesn’t help. That would be more for personal owned machines to connect to internal resources. Maybe B and E are the best here.
D definitely doesn't address the question. VDI won't allow you to monitor web traffic on the host machine.... I think B&E are correct here.

 A cloud provider. Not sure if its hybrid or CASB

discussion.content: Multicloud can host a hybrid cloud, and is typically seen as a way to prevent cloud service downtime. Services like AWS and Microsoft Azure use multicloud solutions.
It's multicloud. The last thing they want to do is hybrid cloud and negate the benefits of cloud. A good article on hybrid and multicloud. https://www.ibm.com/cloud/learn/multicloud

comments.content: On second thought, maybe CASB is correct. We must consider this part of the question: "The migration project includes the following phases . . ." If this were in the planning stages, maybe Multicloud solution would make more sense. But I get the idea CompTIA starting at this point might be significant. Maybe we are supposed to assume the company does not want to go back to the drawing board. Agree about the question being badly worded.
The only stated issue here is availability: "(CISO) is still concerned with the availability requirements of critical company applications." Hard to beat redundancy to insure availability.

discussion.content: On third review, I think the given answer is correct. The question (super poorly phrased) is asking for the next step in the cloud migration plan. The next logical step in the given plan to migrate from on-prem to cloud is to implement a CASB. This will prevent certain types of DOS attacks, prevent certain types of file transfers, and add a layer of credential security to prevent a malicious outsider from hacking into your cloud and disabling your company critical applications. Really really really badly written question, but read closely. CASB is the answer.
hybrid as stated

comments.content: I agree here. They just moved their services to the cloud, it wouldn’t make sense to move the, back. Adding another cloud vendor means likelihood of an outage is very low. Only way I would think different is if there were services that would be available locally that would be lost in the event of an internet outage... but we don’t have any info to suggest that here.

discussion.content:
A. Multicloud
In true CompTIA fashion, this is an unbelievably poorly phrased question and none of the answers are like... great. For an HA cloud solution you don't need multicloud OR hybrid you just set up redundancies across regions (all cloud providers now offer this) which can give you a sub-second RTO/RPO.
I think that using a hybrid cloud will make your services less available, not more. You've just gone to all the effort to get out of the data center because your reliability was bad, so the solution is to pull part of your services back into the data center you just moved out of? No way. It just doesn't make any rational sense.
Of all the bad answers here, multicloud makes the most sense.

C. Hybrid cloud solution. 
The hybrid approach allows the critical company applications to be stored on-site if the CISO is concerned about availability so they have the most control available to them.

comments.content: It seems to me that would add redundancy just as much as a hybrid solution.

discussion.content:
A.
Multicloud
CISO is asking for availability. I think C. Hybrid cloud is the best answer. You can provide redundancy through this solution. The rest do not deal with availability.

comments.content: Agree. CASB does nothing for availability.
